Award.AwardTitle: Limit distributions on homogeneous spaces: Interplay of dynamics and number theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
In a wide variety of questions in number theory one often recognizes symmetries and invariance under group actions; and deep insights can be gained into such problems by understanding dynamics of subgroup actions on homogeneous spaces of Lie groups. In several such instances it is necessary to describe limiting distributions of sequences of translates of smooth measures on submanifolds of homogeneous spaces. Building up further from his earlier work on some typical cases, the principal investigator seeks in this project to develop new techniques in homogeneous dynamics to provide very general natural conditions on the manifolds and translating elements that lead to equidistribution of the limit measures. The work should lead to resolutions of some questions on metric properties of Diophantine approximation, counting integral and rational points on group varieties, and counting points on orbits of geometrically finite groups associated with certain geometric configurations.

From a broader perspective, the research will apply the concepts and methods of ergodic theory and dynamical systems about the long-time behavior of a generic particle in a flow, which is originally a physical problem, to answer questions about deep properties of whole numbers. This conceptual bridge between two very different disciplines uses and influences other areas like representation theory, analysis, and differential geometry, not to mention physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

 Basic outcome of the project is resolution of various questions about asymptotic counting in structures of arithmetic or geometric nature. Our approach involves creating dynamical models called `flows on homogeneous spaces’ where one relates the above counting questions to long time behavior (limiting distributions) of the trajectory of a specific particle in this dynamical system. The core results are dynamical theorems describing the limiting distributions, and relating their geometric properties to number theoretic properties of the original structures for which we do the counting.

For example, we can count the number of circles of curvature (inverse of radius) at most  (very large) lying in some region in an infinite packing of circles in a plane (see the figure) arising out of some geometric construction. Broader impact:

The dynamical model of flows on homogeneous spaces is quite a versetile model for various types of  mathematical problems involving large groups of symmeties. The new techniques developed in our work and general theorems on limit distributions proved have a much greater scope of applications beyond number theory or geometry. 

The work in this project shows interactions between different deciplines in sciences. The dynamical systems are created out of Lie groups, a subject with origin in theoretical Physics and later developed purely from mathematical view point. Then these systems are then analysed using ideas of Ergodic theory, a subject which is the mathematical theory created out of concepts of physics about average behavior of a typical particle in some space - path integral in the limit being equal to the space integral. The work also involves differential geometry and representation theory.

The project provided opportunites to guide graduate students to work on some related aspects of this work.
